detaileddescription.para: creates the undercover primal heuristic and includes it in SCIP

memberdef.argsstring: (SCIP *scip, int *coversize, SCIP_VAR **cover, SCIP_Real timelimit, SCIP_Real memorylimit, SCIP_Real objlimit, SCIP_Bool globalbounds, SCIP_Bool onlyconvexify, SCIP_Bool coverbd, char coveringobj, SCIP_Bool *success)
memberdef.name: SCIPcomputeCoverUndercover

briefdescription.para: pointer to store the variables (of the original SCIP) in the computed cover (should be ready to hold SCIPgetNVars(scip) entries)
objective limit: upper bound on coversize
should global bounds on variables be used instead of local bounds at focus node?
should we only fix/dom.red. variables creating nonconvexity?
should bounddisjunction constraints be covered (or just copied)?
objective function of the covering problem ('b'ranching status, influenced nonlinear 'c'onstraints/'t'erms, 'd'omain size, 'l'ocks, 'm'in of up/down locks, 'u'nit penalties, constraint 'v'iolation)

detaileddescription.para: computes a minimal set of covering variables

Timo Berthold
Ambros Gleixner The undercover heuristic is designed for mixed-integer nonlinear programs and tries to fix a subset of variables such as to make each constraint linear or convex. For this purpose it solves a binary program to automatically determine the minimum number of variable fixings necessary. As fixing values, we use values from the LP relaxation, the NLP relaxation, or the incumbent solution.
